ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:44): imagines the discussion of broken IRIs in Atom would be more useful if people had test results of how feed readers parse URL-ish strings, or data about how many feeds have invalid IRIs

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:46): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: There is a well defined data-gathering mechanism for HTML 5 which is to say, people ay things that should be qualified with data and then you provide the data

4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:46): My main point is that I don't want two URL functions in a browser doing essentially the same thing and it's pretty clear that we need one for HTML that does it like HTML5
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:47): I also wouldn't really want two URL functions in a feed reader and since feed readers ought to handle HTML...

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:48): Web browsers already have a zillion functions (many for doing similar things in slightly different ways), so two functions for parsing URLs wouldn't hurt much
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:49): Every one of those that can be avoided hurts in developer and QA time. Security analysis cost, etc.
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (11:50): I'ts one of the reasons we're still trying to eliminate quirks if feasible. (Either by standardizing on them or removing them.)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:50): It hurts but not a huge amount, and it has to be balanced against the cost of changing every other spec and software product that uses URIs in non-HTML contexts
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:50): grumbles about standards bodies that publish their standards in non-standard formats
